description: Saint Paul: Minnesota Public Utilities Commission has issued the following document:. RE: Comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources. Attached are the comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources.
sourceClass: Government Agencies (U.S.), Government Policy, Local Government, National Government

subjectCode.description: Trading Impact (ICE Codes) Important Corporate Events

text:
Saint Paul: Minnesota Public Utilities Commission has issued the following
document:

Will Seuffert

Executive Secretary

Minnesota Public Utilities Commission

121 7th Place East, Suite 350

St. Paul, Minnesota 55101

RE: Comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy
Resources

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Dear Mr. Seuffert:

Attached are the comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of
Energy Resources

(Department) in the following matter:

Otter Tail Power Company's Petition for Approval of the Annual Forecasted
Rates for its

Energy Adjustment Rider, Rate Schedule 13.01.

The Department recommends approval and is available to answer any questions
that the Minnesota

Public Utilities Commission may have.

Sincerely,

/s/ Samir Ouanes

Public Utilities Rates Analyst

SO/ar

Attachment

Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission

Comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce

Division of Energy Resources

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

I. SUMMARY

On May 14, 2020, Otter Tail Power Company (OTP or the Company) filed a
petition (Petition)

requesting that the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission)
approve:

* its proposed refund of its 2020 year-to-date (January-March 2020) positive fuel cost

(FCA) tracker balance of about $3.7 million to its Minnesota ratepayers; and

* its proposed corresponding $0.0057/kWh reduction of the Commission-approved FCA

charges during the July-September 2020 period.

II. BACKGROUND INFORMATION

On May 1, 2019, OTP filed its 2020 monthly forecasted energy adjustment rates
based on a 2020

forecast of 5,032,227 Megawatt-hours (MWhs) in sales resulting in total 2020
system fuel costs of

$129,715,063, for an average fuel cost of $25.777/MWh.

On July 1, 2019, the Minnesota Department of Commerce \- Division of Energy
Resources (the

Department) filed comments (Department's Comments) recommending adjustments to
the net system

FCA cost and requesting more information from OTP. In particular, the
Department raised the

following two concerns:

* OTP's 2020 system fuel costs included $293,682 in wholesale market charges that were

also recoverable under base rates and/or another rider;1 and

* the forecasted decrease in the MWh of Production Plant in 2020 appears to be

inconsistent with the relatively higher 2020 $/MWh market prices incorporated
in OTP's

Strategist run. This information suggested that the MWh amount of outages
embedded

in OTP's Strategist run was over-estimated.2

On July 31, 2019, OTP filed reply comments with revisions recommended by the
Department, and

additional information. The Company acknowledged the double recovery issue
raised by the

Department and proposed a revised 2020 system fuel costs of $129,421,381, for
an average fuel cost

of $25.719/MWh.

1 Department's Comments at page 18.

2 Department's Comments at page 15.

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Analyst assigned: Samir Ouanes

Page 3

On August 30, 2019, the Department filed a response to OTP's reply comments,
and recommended a

different system FCA cost than the Company, $124,996,398 or a reduction of
about $4.4 million, to

alleviate the cost impact on OTP's ratepayers of the substantial and
unsupported MWh increase in

unplanned outages incorporated in OTP's revised 2020 system fuel cost of
$129,421,381.

Ordering Point 1 of the December 18, 2019 Order in Docket No. E017/AA-19-297
(December 2019

Order) approved OTP's revised forecasted 2020 system FCA costs of $129,421,381
and resulting

monthly FCA rates.3

On May 14, 2020, the Company filed a petition (Petition) requesting that the
Commission approve its

proposed reduction of the fuel cost charges for the July-September 2020 period
in Docket No.

E017/AA-19-297, as a result of OTP's actual costs for January-March 2020 being
$8,477,547 lower than

its Commission-approved January-March 2020 system fuel cost forecast in Docket
No. E017/AA-19-

297.4

On May 22, 2020, the Commission approved OTP's January 30, 2020 compliance
report in Docket No.

E017/M-03-30 and the annual true-up credit of 0.5 mills (0.05 cents) per kWh
to be refunded over the

12-month period beginning March 1, 2020.

On May 27, 2020, the Commission issued a Notice of Shortened Comment Period
(Notice) with the

following topics open for comment:

1\. Is the request consistent with the Commission's June 12, 2019 Order

Approving Additional Details Of New Fuel Clause Adjustment Process

(June 12, 2019 Order)?

2\. Should the Commission approve Otter Tail's request to reduce, for the

months of July through September 2020, its Energy Adjustment Rider

(EAR or FCA) rates by $0.0057/kWh?

3\. Does Commission approval also require a rule variance or a reopening of

the June 12, 2019 Order?

4\. Is the handling of the proposed reduction reasonable?

5\. Can Otter Tail implement the proposed changes as requested without

prior Commission approval?

6\. Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?

The Department addresses the Notice's topics 1, 3 and 5 (legal issues) in
Section III, topics 2 and 4 in

Section IV and topic 6 in Section V.

3 OTP's Commission-approved 2020 forecasted FCA costs and corresponding
monthly FCA rates are identified in Revised

Attachment 2 (line 10) and Revised Attachment 1 (lines 3-12) of OTP's July 31,
2019 reply comments in Docket No.

E017/AA-19-297.

4 Source: Department's calculation based on Table 1 of the Petition.

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Analyst assigned: Samir Ouanes

Page 4

III. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS-LEGAL ISSUES

Ordering Point 3 of the June 12, 2019 Order in Docket No. E999/CI-03-802
stated:

The Commission adopts a threshold of plus or minus 5 percent of all FCA

costs and revenues to determine whether an event qualifies as a significant

unforeseen impact that may justify an adjustment to the approved fuel

rates. The Electric Utilities are permitted to implement revised rates

following a 30-day notice period, subject to a full refund, if no party
objects

to the revised rates.

Attachment 1 of the Petition shows that OTP's actual costs for the first three
months of 2020 met the

Commission's threshold of plus or minus 5 percent of all FCA costs and
revenues to determine whether

an event qualifies as a significant unforeseen impact that may justify an
adjustment to the approved

fuel rates. The Company's ratio of its over-recovery by its energy costs for
the first three months of

2020 is above 25 percent.

According to OTP, "the combination of economic impacts caused by COVID-19,
along with low

natural gas prices and LMPs, qualify as events with 'significant unforeseen
impacts'."5 While the

Company did not address explicitly whether the costs were unforeseeable and
outside of the utility's

control, are expected to continue for the remainder of the year, and are
reasonable to pass on to

ratepayers, per the standard developed by the parties as described on page 6
of the June 12, 2019

Order, it appears that each component is met, as discussed below.6

Specifically, in light of the unprecedented effects of the COVID-19 pandemic
on utility operations,

economic conditions, and consumers' personal finances, the Department supports
OTP's proposal to

reduce its monthly fuel cost charges for all customers as soon as possible.

In addition, the Department notes that low natural gas prices and LMPs may
also qualify as

"unforeseeable and outside of the utility's control." Moreover, as discussed
further under Section V

below, the Department expects OTP's actual costs to continue to be below the
Commission-approved

forecasted rates7 due in part to lower MWh amount of unplanned outages than
embedded in rates.

The Company is simply proposing to provide its first quarter of 2020 over-
recovery of about $3.7

million as a refund to customers sooner (when customers need it most) rather
than waiting for the

annual 2021 true-up that will be processed under the new FCA reform mechanism.

title: Regulatory update: Minnesota Public Utilities Commission; DOC DER, has issued ( 19-297 ) COMMENTS.
html:
Saint Paul: Minnesota Public Utilities Commission has issued the following document:

Will Seuffert

Executive Secretary

Minnesota Public Utilities Commission

121 7th Place East, Suite 350

St. Paul, Minnesota 55101

RE: Comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Dear Mr. Seuffert:

Attached are the comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources

(Department) in the following matter:

Otter Tail Power Company's Petition for Approval of the Annual Forecasted Rates for its

Energy Adjustment Rider, Rate Schedule 13.01.

The Department recommends approval and is available to answer any questions that the Minnesota

Public Utilities Commission may have.

Sincerely,

/s/ Samir Ouanes

Public Utilities Rates Analyst

SO/ar

Attachment

Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission

Comments of the Minnesota Department of Commerce

Division of Energy Resources

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

I. SUMMARY

On May 14, 2020, Otter Tail Power Company (OTP or the Company) filed a petition (Petition)

requesting that the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission) approve:

* its proposed refund of its 2020 year-to-date (January-March 2020) positive fuel cost

On May 1, 2019, OTP filed its 2020 monthly forecasted energy adjustment rates based on a 2020

forecast of 5,032,227 Megawatt-hours (MWhs) in sales resulting in total 2020 system fuel costs of

$129,715,063, for an average fuel cost of $25.777/MWh.

On July 1, 2019, the Minnesota Department of Commerce - Division of Energy Resources (the

Department) filed comments (Department's Comments) recommending adjustments to the net system

* OTP's 2020 system fuel costs included $293,682 in wholesale market charges that were

also recoverable under base rates and/or another rider;1 and

inconsistent with the relatively higher 2020 $/MWh market prices incorporated in OTP's

Strategist run. This information suggested that the MWh amount of outages embedded

in OTP's Strategist run was over-estimated.2

On July 31, 2019, OTP filed reply comments with revisions recommended by the Department, and

additional information. The Company acknowledged the double recovery issue raised by the

Department and proposed a revised 2020 system fuel costs of $129,421,381, for an average fuel cost

of $25.719/MWh.

1 Department's Comments at page 18.

2 Department's Comments at page 15.

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Analyst assigned: Samir Ouanes

Page 3

On August 30, 2019, the Department filed a response to OTP's reply comments, and recommended a

different system FCA cost than the Company, $124,996,398 or a reduction of about $4.4 million, to

alleviate the cost impact on OTP's ratepayers of the substantial and unsupported MWh increase in

unplanned outages incorporated in OTP's revised 2020 system fuel cost of $129,421,381.

Ordering Point 1 of the December 18, 2019 Order in Docket No. E017/AA-19-297 (December 2019

Order) approved OTP's revised forecasted 2020 system FCA costs of $129,421,381 and resulting

monthly FCA rates.3

On May 14, 2020, the Company filed a petition (Petition) requesting that the Commission approve its

proposed reduction of the fuel cost charges for the July-September 2020 period in Docket No.

E017/AA-19-297, as a result of OTP's actual costs for January-March 2020 being $8,477,547 lower than

its Commission-approved January-March 2020 system fuel cost forecast in Docket No. E017/AA-19-

297.4

On May 22, 2020, the Commission approved OTP's January 30, 2020 compliance report in Docket No.

E017/M-03-30 and the annual true-up credit of 0.5 mills (0.05 cents) per kWh to be refunded over the

12-month period beginning March 1, 2020.

On May 27, 2020, the Commission issued a Notice of Shortened Comment Period (Notice) with the

following topics open for comment:

1. Is the request consistent with the Commission's June 12, 2019 Order

Approving Additional Details Of New Fuel Clause Adjustment Process

(June 12, 2019 Order)?

2. Should the Commission approve Otter Tail's request to reduce, for the

months of July through September 2020, its Energy Adjustment Rider

(EAR or FCA) rates by $0.0057/kWh?

3. Does Commission approval also require a rule variance or a reopening of

the June 12, 2019 Order?

4. Is the handling of the proposed reduction reasonable?

5. Can Otter Tail implement the proposed changes as requested without

prior Commission approval?

6. Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?

The Department addresses the Notice's topics 1, 3 and 5 (legal issues) in Section III, topics 2 and 4 in

Section IV and topic 6 in Section V.

3 OTP's Commission-approved 2020 forecasted FCA costs and corresponding monthly FCA rates are identified in Revised

Attachment 2 (line 10) and Revised Attachment 1 (lines 3-12) of OTP's July 31, 2019 reply comments in Docket No.

E017/AA-19-297.

4 Source: Department's calculation based on Table 1 of the Petition.

Docket No. E017/AA-19-297

Analyst assigned: Samir Ouanes

Page 4

III. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS-LEGAL ISSUES

Ordering Point 3 of the June 12, 2019 Order in Docket No. E999/CI-03-802 stated:

The Commission adopts a threshold of plus or minus 5 percent of all FCA

costs and revenues to determine whether an event qualifies as a significant

unforeseen impact that may justify an adjustment to the approved fuel

rates. The Electric Utilities are permitted to implement revised rates

following a 30-day notice period, subject to a full refund, if no party objects

to the revised rates.

Attachment 1 of the Petition shows that OTP's actual costs for the first three months of 2020 met the

Commission's threshold of plus or minus 5 percent of all FCA costs and revenues to determine whether

an event qualifies as a significant unforeseen impact that may justify an adjustment to the approved

2020 is above 25 percent.

According to OTP, "the combination of economic impacts caused by COVID-19, along with low

natural gas prices and LMPs, qualify as events with 'significant unforeseen impacts'."5 While the

Company did not address explicitly whether the costs were unforeseeable and outside of the utility's

economic conditions, and consumers' personal finances, the Department supports OTP's proposal to

"unforeseeable and outside of the utility's control." Moreover, as discussed further under Section V

The Company is simply proposing to provide its first quarter of 2020 over-recovery of about $3.7

million as a refund to customers sooner (when customers need it most) rather than waiting for the

annual 2021 true-up that will be processed under the new FCA reform mechanism.
